sen.j: 細川 忠興／長岡 忠興（ほそかわ ただおき／ながおか ただおき）は、戦国時代 (日本)から江戸時代前期にかけての武将、大名。
sen.e: Tadaoki HOSOKAWA/ Tadaoki NAGAOKA was military leaders and Daimyo (feudal lord) from the Sengoku period (Warring States period) through to the Edo period in Japan.
Tadaoki HOSOKAWA/Tadaoki NAGAOKA was a military leader and Daimyo (feudal lord) from the Sengoku period (Warring States period) through to the Edo period in Japan.
Tadaoki HOSOKAWA/Tadaoki NAGAOKA was a military leader and Daimyo (feudal lord) from the Sengoku period (Warring States period) through to the Edo period in Japan.

sen.j: 丹後国宮津城を経て豊前国小倉藩初代藩主。
sen.e: As feudal lord he was the first to rule over the Kokura han (Kokura Domain) in Buzen-no-kuni (Buzen Province) from Miyazaki Castle in Tango-no-kuni (Tango Province).
He was the first feudal lord to rule over Kokura han (Kokura Domain) in Buzen-no-kuni (Buzen Province) from Miyazaki Castle in Tango-no-kuni (Tango Province).
He was the first feudal lord to rule over Kokura han (Kokura Domain) in Buzen-no-kuni (Buzen Province) from Miyazaki Castle in Tango-no-kuni (Tango Province).

sen.j: また、父・細川幽斎と同じく、教養人・茶人としても有名で、利休七哲の一人に数えられる。
sen.e: Furthermore, like his father Yusai HOSOKAWA, he was a famous master of the tea ceremony and cultivated individual trained by Rikyu shichitetsu (Rikyu seven sages).
Furthermore, like his father Yusai HOSOKAWA, he was an educated man and famous tea master taught by Rikyu shichitetsu (Rikyu seven sages).
Furthermore, like his father Yusai HOSOKAWA, he was an educated man and famous tea master taught by Rikyu shichitetsu (Rikyu seven sages).

sen.j: 茶道の流派三斎流の開祖。
sen.e: He was the founder of the Sansai School of tea ceremony.
He was the founder of the Sansai School of tea ceremony.
He was the founder of the Sansai School of tea ceremony.

sen.j: 実父は幕臣・細川幽斎、養父は一族の細川輝経（細川奥州家）、正室は明智光秀の娘・玉子（通称は細川ガラシャ）。
sen.e: His actual father Yusai HOSOKAWA was a vassal and his adoptive father was a relative of Terutsune HOSOKAWA (Hosokawa-Oshu family), his heir being Mitsuhide AKECHI's daughter Tamako (nicknamed "Gracia HOSOKAWA").

Tadaoki's actual father Yusai HOSOKAWA was a vassal, his adoptive father was a relative of Terutsune HOSOKAWA (Hosokawa-Oshu family), and he married Mitsuhide AKECHI's daughter Tamako (also known as "Gracia HOSOKAWA").

Tadaoki's actual father Yusai HOSOKAWA was a vassal, his adoptive father was a relative of Terutsune HOSOKAWA (Hosokawa-Oshu family), and he married Mitsuhide AKECHI's daughter Tamako (also known as "Gracia HOSOKAWA").
sen.cmt: AKECHI’sの’を'に訂正しました。”を"に訂正しました。

sen.j: 彼名（通称）は与一郎。
sen.e: His name (nickname) was "Yoichiro".
His name (nickname) was "Yoichiro".
His name (nickname) was "Yoichiro."
sen.cmt: ”を"に訂正しました。ピリオド位置訂正しました。

sen.j: 越中守、侍従、丹後宰相。
sen.e: Governor of Echu Province, Chamberlain, Prime Minister of Tango Province
Governor of Echu Province, Chamberlain, Prime Minister of Tango Province
Governor of Echu Province, Chamberlain, Prime Minister of Tango Province.
sen.cmt: ピリオド補足しました。

sen.j: 三斎宗立と号す。
sen.e: Takes the name "Sansai Souryu"
Takes the name "Sansai Souryu"
Takes the name "Sansai souryu."
sen.cmt: ”を"に訂正しました。ピリオド補足しました。

sen.j: 忠興の名は、織田信長の嫡男・織田信忠の偏諱を受けたものである。
sen.e: Tadaoki's name borrows one kanji character from the name of Nobunaga ODA's eldest son, Nobutada ODA.
Tadaoki's name borrows one kanji character from the name of Nobunaga ODA's eldest son, Nobutada ODA.
Tadaoki's name borrows one kanji character from the name of Nobunaga ODA's eldest son, Nobutada ODA.

sen.j: 将軍足利義昭追放後は長岡氏を称し、その後羽柴姓も称していたが、大坂夏の陣の後に細川姓へ復した。
sen.e: After the shogun, Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA, was sent into exile the Hosokawa clan was renamed the Nagaoka clan and later were given the name Hashiba but, following the summer campaign of the siege of Osaka, they reverted to going by the name of "Hosokawa".

After the shogun Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA was sent into exile the Hosokawa clan was renamed the Nagaoka clan and later were given the name Hashiba but reverted to the name of "Hosokawa", following the summer siege of Osaka,

After the shogun Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA was sent into exile the Hosokawa clan was renamed the Nagaoka clan and later were given the name Hashiba but reverted to the name of "Hosokawa," following the summer siege of Osaka,
sen.cmt: ”を"に訂正しました。コンマ位置訂正しました。

sen.j: 足利義昭、織田信長、豊臣秀吉、徳川家康と、時の有力者に仕えて、現在まで続く細川氏の基礎を築いた人物である。
sen.e: He collaborated with important people of the era: Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA, Nobunaga ODA, Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, and Ieyasu TOKUGAWA and is the person who built the foundations of the HOSOKAWA clan which has continued to present times.

Tadaoki collaborated with Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA, Nobunaga ODA, Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, and Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, the powerful people of the era, and is built the foundations of the HOSOKAWA clan which still survives today.

Tadaoki collaborated with Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA, Nobunaga ODA, Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, and Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, the powerful people of the era, and is built the foundations of the HOSOKAWA clan which still survives today.

sen.j: 大正13年2月11日、贈正三位贈呈。
sen.e: Awarded a promotion to the Sho-san-mi court rank (senior grade third rank) on 11 February 1924.
The clan were promoted to Sho-san-mi court rank (senior grade third rank) on 11 February 1924.
sen.cmt: A subject is required here but it is not clear who it should be.
sen.e: Tadaoki was promoted to Shosanmi (Senior Court Rank) on February 11, 1924.
sen.cmt: 主語は忠興と解釈し、訂正しました。正三位、表記及び説明訂正しました。日付の表記訂正しました。

tit.cmt: I think this is more appropriate.

sen.j: 永禄6年（1563年）11月13日、将軍足利義輝に仕える幕臣・細川幽斎の長男として京都で生まれる。
sen.e: Born in Kyoto on 13 Nov 1563 as eldest son of Yusai HOSOKAWA, a vassal in the service of the shogun Yoshiteru ASHIKAGA.
Tadaoki was born in Kyoto on 13 Nov 1563 as eldest son of Yusai HOSOKAWA, a vassal in the service of the shogun Yoshiteru ASHIKAGA.
sen.cmt: I feel a subject is required here.
sen.e: Tadaoki was born in Kyoto on December 8, 1563, as the eldest son of Yusai HOSOKAWA, a vassal in the service of the shogun Yoshiteru ASHIKAGA.
sen.cmt: 日付の表記訂正しました。新暦に訂正しました。The補足しました。

sen.j: 義輝の命により一族・奥州家の細川輝経の養子となるが、この養子縁組は系譜上のものであり、その後も実父・藤孝と行動をともにし、領国も継承した。
sen.e: On Yoshiteru `s orders he became an adopted as a son of Terutsune HOSOKAWA and member of the Oshu family but, as an adopted son he was not part of the family pedigree and, later acted in concert with Fujitaka, his actual father and inherited the fiefdom.

On Yoshiteru's orders was adopted as a son of Terutsune HOSOKAWA and member of the Oshu family but, as an adopted son he was not part of the family line and later cooperated with Fujitaka, his actual father, and inherited the fiefdom.

On Yoshiteru's orders he was adopted as a son of Terutsune HOSOKAWA, a member of the Oshu family, but as an adopted son he was not part of the family line and later cooperated with Fujitaka, his actual father, and inherited the fiefdom.
sen.cmt: he補足しました。コンマ補足、and削除、スペース削除。a補足しました。

sen.j: 永禄の変の後、藤孝や明智光秀らは尾張国・美濃国の大名織田信長を頼って義輝の弟・義昭を将軍に擁立したが、やがて信長と義昭が対立すると信長に臣従した。
sen.e: After the Eiroku-no-hen (the Eiroku Incident), Fujitaka and compatriots of Mitsuhide AKECHI came to rely upon the Owari-no-kuni (Owari Province)/ Mino-no-kuni (Mino Province) daimyo Nobunaga ODA and backed Yoshiteru`s younger brother Yoshiaki as shogun however, in due course, Nobunaga and Yoshiaki had a confrontation and he became a vassal of Nobunaga.

After the Eiroku-no-hen (the Eiroku Incident), Fujitaka and compatriots of Mitsuhide AKECHI came to rely upon the Owari-no-kuni (Owari Province)/ Mino-no-kuni (Mino Province) daimyo Nobunaga ODA and backed Yoshiteru's younger brother Yoshiaki as shogun. However, when Nobunaga and Yoshiaki had a confrontation, Tadaoki became a vassal of Nobunaga.
sen.cmt: It is not clear what connection Fujitaka has to Tadaoki…
sen.e: After the Eiroku no hen (the Eiroku Incident), Fujitaka and Mitsuhide AKECHI came to rely upon daimyo Nobunaga ODA of Owari Province/Mino Province and backed Yoshiteru's younger brother Yoshiaki as shogun, however, Tadaoki became a vassal of Nobunaga when Nobunaga and Yoshiaki had a confrontation.
sen.cmt: ハイフン削除、スペース補足。compatriots of、不要と考え削除しました。尾張国・美濃国の位置を訂正、-no-kuniをProvinceに訂正しました。一原文一訳文の原則に従って、一文に訂正しました。文の構成を訂正しました。

sen.j: 忠興は信長の嫡男・織田信忠に仕えた。
sen.e: Tadaoki served Nobutada ODA, the eldest son of Nobunaga.
Tadaoki served Nobutada ODA, the eldest son of Nobunaga.
Tadaoki served Nobutada ODA, the eldest son of Nobunaga.

sen.j: 天正5年（1577年）、15歳で紀伊国雑賀一揆攻めに加わり初陣を飾る。
sen.e: In 1577 he gained his first battle experience as a 15 year old by taking part in the Kii-no-kuni (Kii Province) Saika insurrection.
In 1577 he gained his first battle experience as a 15 year old by taking part in the Kii-no-kuni (Kii Province) Saika insurrection.
In 1577 Tadaoki gained his first battle experience as a 15 year old by taking part in Saika insurrection of Ki Province.
sen.cmt: HeをTadaokiに訂正しました。紀伊国→Ki no kuni (Ki Province)

sen.j: さらに信長から離反した松永久秀の武将・森秀光が立て籠もる大和国片岡城を父やその僚友・明智光秀と共に落とし、信長直々の感状を受けた。
sen.e: Moreover, he received a direct letter of commendation from Nobunaga for together with his father and his comrade Mitsuhide AKECHI capturing Hidemitsu MORI who had secluded himself in Kataoka Castle in Yamato-no-kuni (Yamato Province). MORI was Hisahide MATSUNAGA's commander, Matsunaga himself having become estranged from Nobunaga.

Moreover, when Hisahide MATSUNAGA turned against Nobunaga and MATSNUGA's commander Hidemitsu MORI holed himself in Kataoka Castle in Yamato-no-kuni (Yamato Province), Tadaoki together with his father and his father's ally Mitsuhide AKECHI captured MORI, for which he received a direct letter of commendation from Nobunaga.
sen.cmt: This structure is easier to understand.
sen.e: Moreover, when Hisahide MATSUNAGA turned against Nobunaga and MATSNUGA's commander Hidemitsu MORI holed himself in Kataoka Castle in Yamato Province, Tadaoki together with his father and his father's ally Mitsuhide AKECHI captured MORI, for which he received a direct letter of commendation from Nobunaga.

sen.j: 天正7年（1579年）には信長の命を受けて、父や光秀と共に丹後国守護だった建部山城城主・一色義道を滅ぼした。
sen.e: In 1579 he received an order from Nobunaga to together with his father and Mitsuhide to overthrow Yoshimichi ISSHIKI, the then govenor of Tango Province who was lord of Takebeyama Castle.
In 1579, on orders from Nobunaga, Tadaoki, his father and Mitsuhide overthrew Yoshimichi ISSHIKI, the military governor of Tango Province and lord of Takebeyama Castle.
In 1579, on orders from Nobunaga, Tadaoki, his father and Mitsuhide overthrew Yoshimichi ISSHIKI, the military governor of Tango Province and lord of Takebeyama Castle.

sen.j: 天正7年（1579年）、信長の仲介を受けて、光秀の三女・玉子（細川ガラシャ）と結婚する。
sen.e: In 1579 received a marriage introduction from Nobunaga for the hand of Mitsuhide's 3rd daughter Tamako (Gracia HOSOKAWA).
In 1579 he married Mitsuhide's 3rd daughter Tamako (Gracia HOSOKAWA) with Nobunaga as the matchmaker.
sen.cmt: All sentences thus far have included a subject, so I think one is needed here too.
sen.e: In 1579 he married Mitsuhide's 3rd daughter Tamako (Gracia HOSOKAWA) with Nobunaga as the matchmaker.

sen.j: この時、信長の命により九曜を定紋とし、これが細川家の家紋となった。
sen.e: At that time, he was ordered by Nobunaga to use the Kuyo (nine-planet crest) motif for his family crest which was then adopted as the family crest of the HOSOKAWA clan.
On his marraige, he was permitted by Nobunaga to use the Kuyo (nine-planet crest) motif for his family crest, and this was then adopted as the family crest of the HOSOKAWA clan.
On his marriage, he was permitted by Nobunaga to use the Kuyo (nine-planet crest) motif for his family crest, and this was then adopted as the family crest of the Hosokawa clan.
sen.cmt: marriageスペル訂正しました。Hosokawa に訂正しました。

sen.j: 以前、忠興が信長の小刀の柄に九曜が描かれているのを大変気に入っていたことを信長が覚えていたためと言われる。
sen.e: It is said it was because Nobunaga recalled that previously, Tadaoki was most taken by the Kuyo (nine-planet crest) motif which was etched on the hilt of Nobunaga's short sword.
It is said that Nobunaga did this because he remembered how taken Tadaoki had been by the Kuyo (nine-planet crest) motif etched on the hilt of his (Nobunaga's) short sword.
It is said that Nobunaga did this because he remembered how taken Tadaoki had been by the Kuyo (nine-planet crest) motif etched on the hilt of his (Nobunaga's) short sword.

sen.j: 天正8年（1580年）、父・藤孝は功により丹後一国12万石の領主となる。
sen.e: In 1580 his father Fujitaka was awarded a 120,000 koku title as lord of Tango Province.
In 1580 his father Fujitaka was awarded the title of lord of Tango Province with a stipend of 120,000 koku.
In 1580 his father Fujitaka was awarded the title of lord of Tango Province with a stipend of 120,000 koku.

sen.j: 天正10年（1582年）6月、岳父・明智光秀が本能寺の変を起こし藤孝・忠興父子を味方に誘ったが、父子は誘いを拒否したうえ、玉子を丹後国の味土野（現在の京丹後市弥栄町須川付近）に幽閉した。
sen.e: In June 1582, his father-in-law Mitsuhide AKECHI incited the Honnoji Incident and father and son Fujitaka and Tadaoki were called upon to provide support however, father and son lined the offer and furthermore, Tamako was imprisoned in Midono ni Tango Province (present day vicinity of Sugawa, Yasaka-cho, Kyotango City).

In June 1582, Tadaoki's father-in-law Mitsuhide AKECHI instigated the Honnoji Incident and called upon Tadaoki and his father Fujitaka to provide support however, but they refused and Tamako was imprisoned in Midono ni Tango Province (vicinity of present-day Sugawa, Yasaka-cho, Kyotango City).

In June 1582, Tadaoki's father-in-law Mitsuhide AKECHI instigated the Honnoji Incident and called upon Tadaoki and his father Fujitaka to provide support however, but they refused and Tamako was imprisoned in Midono in Tango Province (vicinity of present-day Sugawa, Yasaka-cho, Kyotango City).

sen.j: 幽閉されていた屋敷跡に「女城跡（御殿屋敷）」が現在も建っている。
sen.e: To this day, the remains of the mansion where she was confined "Mejiro-ato" (Goten-yashiki) still stand.
The remains of the mansion where she was confined "Mejiro-ato" (Goten-yashiki) still stand today.
The remains of the mansion where she was confined 'Mejiro-ato' (Goten-yashiki) still stand today.
sen.cmt: 原文の「」に合わせて”を'に訂正しました。

sen.j: 細川父子にまで見捨てられたことは、光秀の滅亡を決定的にしたといわれている。
sen.e: Being abandoned by even HOSOKAWA father and son is said to have been decisive in the downfall of Mitsuhide.
Being abandoned by even HOSOKAWA father and son is said to have been decisive in the downfall of Mitsuhide.
Being abandoned by even Hosokawa father and son is said to have been decisive in the downfall of Mitsuhide.

sen.j: 忠興はこのとき、父から領国を譲られて丹後宮津城主となった。
sen.e: At that time, Tadaoki received a fiefdom from his father and became the lord of Tango-Miyazu Castle.
Around the same time, Tadaoki received a fiefdom from his father and became the lord of Tango-Miyazu Castle.
Around the same time, Tadaoki received a fiefdom from his father and became the lord of Tango-Miyazu Castle.

sen.j: この後、天下統一を推し進める羽柴秀吉（豊臣秀吉）に仕えた。
sen.e: Afterwards, progress was made towards unifying the country and he served Hideyoshi HASHIBA (Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI).
He later served Hideyoshi HASHIBA (Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI) who was making progress towards unifying the country.
sen.cmt: Surely "Tadaoki" is the subject of this sentence.
sen.e: He later served Hideyoshi HASHIBA (Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI) who was making progress towards unifying the country.

sen.j: 天正12年（1584年）の小牧・長久手の戦いに参加し、翌13年（1585年）には従四位下、侍従に叙任し、秀吉から羽柴姓を与えられた（大坂夏の陣終了後まで羽柴姓を継続）。
sen.e: In 1584, he took part in the Battle of Komaki Nagakute and in the following year (1585) he was invested as chamberlain Ju-shii-ge (lower grade third rank).
In 1584, he took part in the Battle of Komaki Nagakute and in the following year (1585) Hideyoshi appointed him as chamberlain Ju-shii-ge (lower grade third rank).

In 1584, Tadaoki took part in the Battle of Komaki Nagakute, and in the following year (1585) he was promoted to the rank of Jushiinoge (Junior Forth Rank, Lower Grade), appointed to the position of Jiju (chamberlain) and given the family name "Hashiba" by Hideyoshi (this name continued to be used until the end of Osaka Natsu no Jin (Summer Siege of Osaka)).
sen.cmt: 用語集より、従四位下→Jushiinoge (Junior Forth Rank, Lower Grade)侍従→Jiju訂正しました。「秀吉から羽柴姓を与えられた（大坂夏の陣終了後まで羽柴姓を継続）。」の訳抜けを訳しました。

sen.j: その後も天正15年（1587年）の九州征伐、天正18年（1590年）の小田原征伐、文禄元年（1592年）からの文禄・慶長の役などに参陣し、武功を挙げた。
sen.e: Later his military exploits were seen participating in: the Kyushu Campaign of 1587, the Odawara Campaign of 1590, and the Buncho Keicho no Eki (Japanese Invasions of Korea in 1592 and 1597).
Thereafter, his military exploits included: the Kyushu Campaign of 1587, the Odawara Campaign of 1590, and the Buncho Keicho no Eki (Japanese Invasions of Korea in 1592 and 1597).
Thereafter, his military exploits included: the Kyushu Campaign of 1587, the Odawara Campaign of 1590, and the the Bunroku-Keicho War (Japanese Invasions of Korea in 1592 and 1597).
sen.cmt: 文禄・慶長の役→the Bunroku-Keicho War

sen.j: 慶長3年（1598年）8月に秀吉が死去すると、武功派大名の一人として石田三成ら吏僚派と対立し、徳川家康と誼を通じた。
sen.e: In August 1598, with the advent of Hideyoshi's death, as a daimyo (feudal lord) of the military faction in his own right, he was in conflict with Mitsunari ISHIDA and his comrades in the official`s faction, and was on good terms with Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.

When Hideyoshi died in 1598, Tadaoki, now a daimyo (feudal lord) of the military faction in his own right, was in conflict with Mitsunari ISHIDA and his comrades in the adminastrative faction and on good terms with Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.

When Hideyoshi died in 1598, Tadaoki, now a daimyo (feudal lord) of the military faction in his own right, was in conflict with Mitsunari ISHIDA and his comrades in the administrative faction and on good terms with Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.

sen.j: 慶長4年（1599年）には加藤清正、福島正則、加藤嘉明、浅野幸長、池田輝政、黒田長政らと共に、三成襲撃に加わった。
sen.e: In 1599 together with: Kiyomasa KATO, Masanori FUKUSHIMA, Yoshiaki KATO, Yoshinaga ASANO, Terumasa IKEDA, and Nagamasa KURODA, he participated in attacks on Mitsunari.
In 1599, he participated in attacks on Mitsunari together with Kiyomasa KATO, Masanori FUKUSHIMA, Yoshiaki KATO, Yoshinaga ASANO, Terumasa IKEDA, and Nagamasa KURODA.
In 1599, he participated in attacks on Mitsunari together with Kiyomasa KATO, Masanori FUKUSHIMA, Yoshiaki KATO, Yoshinaga ASANO, Terumasa IKEDA, and Nagamasa KURODA.

sen.j: 同年、家康から豊後杵築6万石を加増されている。
sen.e: In the same year, he received an additional 60,000 koku of Bungo-kitsuki region land from Ieyasu.
In the same year, he received an additional land in the Bungo-kitsuki region with a yield of 60,000 koku from Ieyasu.
sen.cmt: I think "koku" is a measure of rice rather than of land.
sen.e: In the same year, he received an additional land in the Bungo-Kitsuki region with a yield of 60,000 koku from Ieyasu.

sen.j: 慶長5年（1600年）の関ヶ原の戦いでは東軍に与した。
sen.e: In 1600 the Eastern Army takes part in the Battle of Sekigahara.
In 1600 the Eastern Army took part in the Battle of Sekigahara.
In 1600 the Eastern Army took part in the Battle of Sekigahara.

sen.j: このとき、豊臣恩顧の有力大名であるうえ、父と正室が在京していたため、その去就が注目されたが、東軍に入ることをいち早く表明したため、他の豊臣恩顧の大名に影響を与えたと言われている。
sen.e: At that time, besides being an influential daimyo (feudal lord) of Toyotomi, because his father and heir were ensconced in Tokyo, his commitment was noticed however, because he promptly declared he would join the Eastern army, it is said this influenced other daimyos under Toyotomi's patronage.

At that time, Tadaoki was an influential daimyo (feudal lord) of Toyotomi and had his wife and father in Kyoto, and so the other daimyo were paying close attention to his next move. The prompt announcement of his intention to join the Eastern army is therefore said to have influenced other daimyos who has been under Toyotomi's patronage.

At that time, Tadaoki was an influential daimyo (feudal lord) of Toyotomi and had his wife and father in Kyoto, and so the other daimyo were paying close attention to his next move, however, the prompt announcement of his intention to join the Eastern army is therefore said to have influenced other daimyos who has been under Toyotomi's patronage.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の原則に従って、一文に訂正しました。’を'に訂正しました。

sen.j: 伏見に人質として留め置かれていた妻のガラシャは西軍の襲撃を受け、人質となることを拒んで自害している。
sen.e: Gracia, his wife who was being held as a prisoner at Fushimi came under attack by the Western army but refusing to be taken hostage, commits suicide.
Gracia, his wife, who was confined in Fushimi came under attack by the Western army, and, refusing to be taken hostage, committed suicide.
sen.cmt: The wikipedia page on Gracia Hosokawa states that she was killed by a Hosokawa retainer.
sen.e: Gracia, his wife, who was confined in Fushimi came under attack by the Western army, and, refusing to be taken hostage, committed suicide.

sen.j: また、父の幽斎は忠興の留守を守り丹後田辺城に籠城したが（田辺城の戦い）、朝廷からの勅命により関ヶ原の戦い前に開城し敵将前田茂勝の丹波亀山城に入った。
sen.e: Furthermore, in Tadaoki's absence his father Yusai came under siege (the Battle of Tanabe Castle) while protecting Tango-Tanabe Castle however, in accordance with an imperial order from the Imperial Court, he capitulated the castle prior to the Battle of Sekigahara and entered the enemy commander Shigekatsu MAEDA's Tanba-Kameyama Castle.

Yusai, Tadaoki's father was defending Tango-Tanabe castle in Tadaoki's absence and came under siege (the Battle of Tanabe Castle). However, in accordance with an imperial order from the Imperial Court, he gave up the castle prior to the Battle of Sekigahara and was taken to Tamba-Kameyam castle which was constrolled by enemy commander Shigekatsu MAEDA.

Yusai, Tadaoki's father was defending Tango-Tanabe Castle in Tadaoki's absence and came under siege (the Battle of Tanabe Castle), however, in accordance with an imperial order from the Imperial Court, he gave up the castle prior to the Battle of Sekigahara and was taken to Tanba-Kameyam Castle which was controlled by enemy commander Shigekatsu MAEDA.
sen.cmt: controlledスペル訂正しました。Castle大文字にしました。一原文一訳文の原則に従って、一文に訂正しました。Tanbaに訂正しました。

sen.j: 忠興は9月15日の関ヶ原本戦で石田三成隊と激闘を演じた功績から、戦後の慶長7年（1602年）、家康から豊前国中津藩39万9000石に加増移封された。
sen.e: Because of merit Tadaoki achieved in engaging in fierce fighting with Mitsunari ISHIDA's troops in the central battles of the Battle of Sekigahara on 15 September, after the battle in 1602, Tadaoki' was assigned an additional landholding in Nakatsu-han (Nakatsu Domain) in Buzen-no-kuni (Buzen Province) by Ieyasu's order.

Because of Tadaoki's success in the fierce fighting with Mitsunari ISHIDA's troops at the Battle of Sekigahara on 15 September, Ieyasu in 1602 gave him additional land in Nakatsu-han (Nakatsu Domain) in Buzen-no-kuni (Buzen Province) with a yield of 399,000 koku.

Because of Tadaoki's success in the fierce fighting with Mitsunari ISHIDA's troops at the Battle of Sekigahara on September 15, Ieyasu in 1602 gave him additional land in Nakatsu Domain in Buzen Province with a yield of 399,000 koku.
sen.cmt: ’を'に訂正しました。日付の表記を訂正しました。Nakatsu-han (）は不要と考え削除しました。Buzen-no-kuni ()削除しました。

sen.j: その後、豊前国小倉に移った。
sen.e: Afterwards he moved to Kokura in Buzen-no-kuni (Buzen Province).
He then moved to Kokura in Buzen-no-kuni (Buzen Province).
He then moved to Kokura in Buzen Province.

sen.j: 慶長19年（1614年）からの大坂の役では、徳川方として参戦する。
sen.e: From 1614 he fought on TOKUGAWA`s side in the Siege of Osaka.
He was on the TOKUGAWA side in the Siege of Osaka, which started in 1614.
sen.cmt: Clarity. I think 1614 is the date that the siege started, not the date that Tadaoki joined the Tokugawa side.
sen.e: He was on the TOKUGAWA side in the Siege of Osaka, which started in 1614.

sen.j: ただし、大坂の役には参戦していない。
sen.e: However, in fact he did not fight in the Osaka campaign.
However, he did not in fact fight in the Osaka campaign.
sen.cmt: I think it reads better like this.
sen.e: However, he did not in fact fight in the Osaka campaign.

sen.j: 元和6年（1620年）、三男の細川忠利に家督を譲って隠居する。
sen.e: In 1620 he transferred control of the family estate to his third son Tadatoshi HOSOKAWA.
In 1620 he transferred control of the family estate to his third son Tadatoshi HOSOKAWA.
In 1620 he transferred control of the family estate to his third son Tadatoshi HOSOKAWA.

sen.j: 寛永9年（1632年）、忠利が肥後国熊本藩54万石の領主として熊本城に移封されると熊本の南の八代城に入り北の丸を隠居所とした。
sen.e: In 1632 he made his place for retirement the Kita-no-maru (Northern ring) of Yatsushiro Castle in South Kumamoto whereas, Tadatoshi became feudal lord of 540,000 koku of land in Kumamoto-han (Kumamoto Domain) in Higo-no-kuni (Higo Province) and moved to Kumamoto Castle.

In 1632, when Tadatoshi became feudal lord of land in Kumamoto-han (Kumamoto Domain) in Higo-no-kuni (Higo Province) with yield of 540,000 koku and moved to Kumamoto Castle, Tadaoki decided to retire to the Kita-no-maru (Northern ring) of Yatsushiro Castle in South Kumamoto.

In 1632, when Tadatoshi became feudal lord of land in Kumamoto Domain in Higo Province with yield of 540,000 koku and moved to Kumamoto Castle, Tadaoki decided to retire to the Kita-no-maru (the north keep) of Yatsushiro Castle in South Kumamoto.
sen.cmt: in Kumamoto Domain in Higo Provinceとしました。北の丸の説明を訂正しました、(the north keep)

sen.j: このとき忠興に従って八代郡高田郷に移った金尊楷と長男の忠兵衛によって高田焼が創始された。
sen.e: At the time, at Tadaoki's direction, Chon-Hae KIM (aka Sonkai KIN) and his eldest son Chubei established Koda-yaki (Koda ceramics) at a place called Koda-go (Koda hamlet) in Yatsushiro-gun (Yatsushiro County).

Around this time, under Tadaoki's instructions, Chon-Hae KIM (aka Sonkai KIN) and his eldest son Chubei established Koda-yaki (Koda ceramics) at a place called Koda-go (Koda hamlet) in Yatsushiro-gun (Yatsushiro County).
sen.cmt: Changed initial part to more natural English
sen.e: Around this time, under Tadaoki's instructions, Chon-Hae KIM (aka Sonkai KIN) and his eldest son Chube established Koda-yaki (Koda ceramics) at a place called Koda-go (Koda hamlet) in Yatsushiro County.
sen.cmt: 忠兵衛→Chubeに訂正しました。’を'に訂正しました。in Yatsushiro Countyとしました。

sen.j: 忠興は四男の細川立孝を八代城本丸に住まわせ、いずれ自分の隠居料9万5千石を継がせて立藩させることを望んでいたようだが、正保2年（1645年)閏5月に立孝は若くして没し、忠興も同年12月2日に没した。
sen.e: Tadaoki's fourth son Tatsutaka HOSOKAWA was made to live in the main keep of Yatsushiro Castle and it appeared that he eventually wanted the retirement gratuity of 95,000 koku to continue and to set up his own clan but, in May 1645 he passed away at a young age and Tadaoki died in December the same year.

Tadaoki had his fourth son Tatsutaka HOSOKAWA live in the main keep of Yatsushiro Castle and seemed to desire him to inherit the retirement gratuity of 95,000 koku and establish his own domain, but he died young in May 1645 and Tadaoki followed him in December of the same year.

Tadaoki had his fourth son Tatsutaka HOSOKAWA live in the main keep of Yatsushiro Castle and seemed to desire him to inherit the retirement gratuity of 95,000 koku and establish his own domain, but he died young in May 1645 and Tadaoki followed him in January 18, 1646.

sen.j: 享年83。
sen.e: He died at 83.
He was 83.
sen.cmt: This form is better if it follows 76 immediately.
sen.e: He was 83.

sen.j: 八代城には立孝の子・宮松（細川行孝）が残されたが、藩主細川光尚（忠利の子）はこれに宇土郡・益城郡内から3万石を与えて宇土支藩とし、筆頭家老松井興長（長岡佐渡守）を八代3万石の城主（正式には城代）とした。
sen.e: Tatsutaka`s son Miyamatsu (Yukitaka HOSOKAWA) remained at Yatsushiro Castle however, the head of the clan Mitsunao HOSOKAWA (Tadatoshi's child), his Uto-gun clan earned 30,000 koku from within Uto-gun and Mashiki-gun and top retainer on his list was Okinaga MATSUI (Nagaoka-Sado-no-kami) who was made feudal lord (formally "castle chamberlain") of Yatsushiro Castle with its 30,000 koku income.

Tatsutaka's son Miyamatsu (Yukitaka HOSOKAWA) remained at Yatsushiro Castle, but the head of the clan Mitsunao HOSOKAWA (Tadatoshi's son) gave him land with a yield of 30,000 koku in Uto-gun and Mashiki-gun and made his top retainer Okinaga MATSUI (Nagaoka-Sado-no-kami) lord (formally "castle chamberlain") of Yatsushiro Castle with its income of 30,000 koku.

Tatsutaka's son Miyamatsu (Yukitaka HOSOKAWA) remained at Yatsushiro Castle, but the head of the clan Mitsunao HOSOKAWA (Tadatoshi's son) gave him land with a yield of 30,000 koku in Uto-gun and Mashiki-gun and made his top retainer Okinaga MATSUI (the governor of Nagaoka-Sado Province) the castellan (formally "the keeper of castle") of Yatsushiro Castle with its income of 30,000 koku.
sen.cmt: （長岡佐渡守）→(Nagaoka-Sado no kami (the governor of Sado Province))城主→the castellan城代→the keeper of castle’を'に訂正しました。

sen.j: 興長の跡は養子・寄之（忠興の六男）が嗣いでいる。
sen.e: Okinaga's heir was his son-in-law Yoriyuki, (Tadaoki's 6th son).
Okinaga's heir was his adopted son Yoriyuki, (Tadaoki's 6th son).
sen.cmt: I think "adopted son" is better than "son-in-law".
sen.e: Okinaga's heir was his adopted son Yoriyuki, (Tadaoki's 6th son).

tit.cmt: 用語統一リストより、人物→Personal Profile

sen.j: 忠興は大変な戦上手で、政治家としても優れていた。
sen.e: Tadaoki was skillful in battle and an excellent politician as well.
Tadaoki was skillful in battle and an excellent politician as well.
Tadaoki was skillful in battle and an excellent politician as well.

sen.j: また忠興は戦国武将の中でも織田信長に劣らぬほどの冷徹さと気性の激しさを持っていた。
sen.e: Furthermore, amongst the military commanders during Japan's Sengoku period (Warring States period) Tadaoki had a disposition just as cool-headed and as intense as Nobunaga ODA.
Among the military commanders of Japan's Sengoku period (Warring States period), only Tadaoki matched Nobunaga ODA in cool-headness and intensity.
Among the military commanders of Japan's Sengoku period (Warring States period), only Tadaoki matched Nobunaga ODA in level-headedness and intensity.
sen.cmt: level-headednessに訂正しました。’を'に訂正しました。

sen.j: 足利氏、織田氏、豊臣氏、徳川氏と多くの主君に仕えながら細川氏を生き延びさせた政治手腕の反面、身内の者にも容赦を加えない苛烈な側面もあり、関ヶ原の合戦中、実父の細川幽斎が居城を敵に明け渡した（詳細は田辺城の戦いの項を参照のこと）ことから一時不和になっている。
sen.e: HOSOKAWA who served many lords including: ASHIKAGA, ODA, TOKUGAWA, survived and prospered thanks to his political skills on the one hand and on the other, he never asked for forgiveness for his stern side from those close to him. When his real father Yusai HOSOKAWA gave up his hold of the castle to the enemy during the Battle of Sekigahara (for details refer to the paragraph on the Battle of Tanabe Castle) a period of discord ensued as a result.

That Tadaoki served many lords including ASHIKAGA, ODA and TOKUGAWA while ensuring that the HOSOKAWA clan continued to prosper is testament to his political skills. However, he was not a man given to forgive, even when it was someone close to him, and this led him to fall out with his father Yusai HOSOKAWA after he (Yusai) surrendered a castle to the enemy during the Battle of Sekigahara (for details refer to the paragraph on the Battle of Tanabe Castle).

That Tadaoki served many lords including Ashikaga, Oda and Tokugawa while ensuring that the Hosokawa clan continued to prosper is testament to his political skills; however, he was not a man given to forgive, even when it was someone close to him, and this led him to fall out with his father Yusai HOSOKAWA after he (Yusai) surrendered a castle to the enemy during the Battle of Sekigahara (for details refer to the paragraph on the Battle of Tanabe Castle).
sen.cmt: 大文字を小文字に訂正しました。一原文一訳文の原則に従って、一文に訂正しました。

sen.j: また、弟の細川興元とも不仲であった。
sen.e: Also, he did not get on well with his younger brother Okimoto HOSOKAWA.
He did not get on well with his younger brother Okimoto HOSOKAWA either.
He did not get on well with his younger brother Okimoto HOSOKAWA either.

sen.j: 忠興は情報戦にも長けていたが、その背景には、当代一流の文化人の一人として数多くの文化人や公卿たちとの交流が盛んだったという事情がある。
sen.e: Tadaoki also excelled at intelligence battles however, putting this into perspective, it is said that the fact is he was one of the most cultured individuals of his day and actively maintained exchanges with many intellectuals and court nobles.

Tadaoki also excelled in information warfare, something which may be linked to his being one of the most cultured men of his day and having frequent interaction with a great number of intellectuals and court nobles.

Tadaoki also excelled in information warfare, something which may be linked to his being one of the most cultured men of his day and having frequent interaction with a great number of intellectuals and court nobles.

sen.j: 隠居後も、土井利勝や遠戚関係にあった春日局などを通して多くの情報を得ていたとされる。
sen.e: Even after retiring, he was able to acquire much information via sources such as Toshikatsu DOI and his distant relative Kasuga-no-tsubone.
Even after retiring, he was able to acquire much information via sources such as Toshikatsu DOI and his distant relative Kasuga-no-tsubone.
Even after retiring, he was able to acquire much information via sources such as Toshikatsu DOI and his distant relative Kasuga no tsubone.
sen.cmt: 春日局、ハイフン削除、スペース補足。

sen.j: ちなみに忠興が生涯で書いた手紙の枚数は、関ヶ原の戦いの後だけでも約2000通が確認されている。
sen.e: As an aside, the number of letters Tadaoki wrote during his lifetime has been confirmed at approximately 2,000, solely in that period of time after the Battle of Sekigahara.
Tadaoki wrote an enormous number of letters during his lifetime, including approximately 2,000 after the Battle of Sekigahara.
Tadaoki wrote an enormous number of letters during his lifetime, including approximately 2,000 after the Battle of Sekigahara.

sen.j: 文化人として
sen.e: Intellectual Pursuits
Intellectual Pursuits
Intellectual Pursuits

sen.j: 父と同じ教養人でもあり、和歌や能楽、絵画にも通じた文化人であった。
sen.e: Like his father, Tadaoki was a cultured individual who expressed his refinement through Waka (classical Japanese poetry form), Noh plays and painting.
Like his father, Tadaoki was a cultured individual who expressed his refinement through Waka (classical Japanese poetry form), Noh plays and painting.
Like his father, Tadaoki was a cultured individual who expressed his refinement through Waka (classical Japanese poetry form), Noh plays and painting.

sen.j: 「細川三斎茶書」という著書を残している。
sen.e: His literacy is "Hosokawa Sansai Chasho" ("Books of Tea by Hosokawa Sansai").
His literacy is "Hosokawa Sansai Chasho" ("Books of Tea by Hosokawa Sansai").
His literacy is 'Hosokawa Sansai Chasho' (Books of Tea by Hosokawa Sansai).
sen.cmt: 原文の「」に合わせて”を'に訂正しました。" "削除。

sen.j: 千利休に師事し、利休に最も気に入られていた弟子で、利休七哲の一人に数えられる。
sen.e: He studied under SEN-no-Rikyu, and as one of Rikyu's favorite pupils and counted as one of "Rikyu's 7 sages".
He studied under SEN-no-Rikyu, and as one of Rikyu's favorite pupils, is counted as one of "Rikyu's 7 sages".
He studied under SEN no Rikyu, and as one of Rikyu's favorite pupils, is counted as one of Rikyu's 7 sages.
sen.cmt: ハイフン削除、スペース補足。’を'に訂正しました。原文に合わせて” ”削除しました。

sen.j: 利休が切腹を命じられたとき、利休にゆかりのある諸大名の中で、見舞いに行った者は、忠興と古田重然だけであったとされる。
sen.e: When Rikyu was ordered to commit ritual suicide, from amongst various Daimyo (feudal lords) only Tadaoki and Shigenari FURUTA attend the scene.
Of the Daimyo with whom Rikyu had a connection, only Tadaoki and Shigenari FURUTA went to visit him after he was ordered to commit ritual suicide.
Of the Daimyo with whom Rikyu had a connection, only Tadaoki and Shigenari FURUTA went to visit him after he was ordered to commit ritual suicide.

sen.j: また、日本刀の著名な拵えの形式である肥後拵の考案者としてもその名を残している。
sen.e: Also, his name is linked with the invention of the celebrated Higo-koshirae (Higo style) form of Japanese sword.
Tadaoki's name is also linked with the invention of the celebrated Higo-koshirae (Higo style) form of Japanese sword.
Tadaoki's name is also linked with the invention of the celebrated Higo-koshirae (Higo style) form of Japanese sword.

sen.j: 夫婦仲
sen.e: Married Life
Married Life
Married Life

sen.j: 正室の玉（洗礼名ガラシャ）への愛情は深く、その父・明智光秀が本能寺の変を起こしたときも離縁せずに、幽閉して累の及ぶのを避けている。
sen.e: His love for his wife, Tama (baptismal name "Gracia"), was deep and even when her father Mitsuhide AKECHI incited the Honnoji Incident, without divorcing her he was forced to imprison her to avoid trouble.
He deeply loved wife, Tama (baptismal name "Gracia"), and managed to avoid having to cut his connection with her after her father Mitsuhide AKECHI instigated the Honnoji Incident by imprisoning her.
He deeply loved wife, Tama (baptismal name "Gracia"), and managed to avoid having to cut his connection with her after her father Mitsuhide AKECHI instigated the Honnoji Incident by imprisoning her.

sen.j: 二人は当代第一の美男美女夫婦といわれたが、玉が秀吉の禁教令発布直後にキリシタンになったとき、これに激怒して侍女の鼻をそぎ、さらに玉を脅迫して改宗を迫ったと言われている。
sen.e: In their day they were said to have been the most handsome couple but when Gracia became a Christian directly after the promulgation of Hideyoshi's edicts prohibiting religion, he flew into a rage and sliced off the nose of her maid-in-waiting and moreover, coerced Tama into converting it is said.

In their day they were said to have been the most handsome couple in Japan, but their relations were not always harmonious. It is said that When Gracia became a Christian directly after the release of Hideyoshi's edicts prohibiting Christianity, he flew into a rage, sliced off the nose of her maid-in-waiting and forced Tama into converting back.
sen.cmt: Readability. Added "but their relations were not always harmonious".
sen.e: In their day they were said to have been the most handsome couple in Japan, but their relations were not always harmonious; it is said that when Gracia became a Christian directly after the release of Hideyoshi's edicts prohibiting Christianity, he flew into a rage, sliced off the nose of her maid-in-waiting and forced Tama into converting back.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の原則に従って、一文に訂正しました。’を'に訂正しました。

sen.j: 更に玉の美しさに見とれた植木職人を手討ちにしたという話もある。
sen.e: Moreover, it is also said he had a gardener who was captivated by Tama`s beauty put to death.
It is also said he had a gardener who was captivated by Tama's beauty put to death.
It is also said he had a gardener who was captivated by Tama's beauty put to death.

sen.j: また、文禄・慶長の役中、忠興は玉に何通もの手紙を書いている。
sen.e: Also, during the Imjin War (1592-1597), Tadaoki wrote Tama numerous letters.
During the Imjin War (1592-1597), Tadaoki wrote Tama numerous letters.
During the the Bunroku-Keicho War, Tadaoki wrote Tama numerous letters.
sen.cmt: 文禄・慶長の役→the Bunroku-Keicho War

sen.j: その内容は秀吉の誘惑に乗らないようにというものだったという。
sen.e: The details of which were to avoid her being seduced by Hideyoshi, so the story goes.
The point of the letters was to avoid her being seduced by Hideyoshi, or so the story goes.
The point of the letters was to avoid her being seduced by Hideyoshi, or so the story goes.

sen.j: 子孫
sen.e: Offspring
Offspring
Offspring

sen.j: 玉との間には3男2女が生まれているが、熊本藩主を継いだ細川忠利は三男である。
sen.e: Tadaoki and Tama had 3 boys and 2 girls but it was his 3rd son, Tadatoshi HOSOKAWA who succeeded him as feudal lord of the Kumamoto domain.
Tadaoki and Tama had 3 boys and 2 girls but it was his 3rd son, Tadatoshi HOSOKAWA who succeeded him as feudal lord of the Kumamoto domain.
Tadaoki and Tama had 3 boys and 2 girls but it was his 3rd son, Tadatoshi HOSOKAWA who succeeded him as feudal lord of the Kumamoto Domain.

sen.j: ちなみに、熊本藩細川家8代藩主細川斉茲は忠利の異母弟細川立孝の系統である支藩宇土藩からの養子である。
sen.e: As an aside, Narishige HOSOKAWA the 8th generation feudal lord of the Kumamoto Hosokawa clan had lineage of a different mother to younger brother Tatsutaka HOSOKAWA having been adopted from the Uto-han (Uto Domain).

Note that Narishige HOSOKAWA the 8th generation feudal lord of the Kumamoto Hosokawa clan was adopted from the Uto-han (Uto Domain) and thus had a different mother to younger brother Tatsutaka HOSOKAWA
Note that Narishige HOSOKAWA the 8th generation feudal lord of the Kumamoto Hosokawa clan was adopted from the Uto Domain and thus had a different mother to younger brother Tatsutaka HOSOKAWA

sen.j: そのため、以後の熊本藩主や細川護煕は斉茲の男系子孫であって、ガラシャの血をひく忠利の男系直系子孫ではない。
sen.e: For that reason, the following lord of the Kumamoto Domain and Morihiro HOSOKAWA was related through male lineage to Narishige HOSOKAWA but not related to the Tadatoshi`s male lineage that has blood ties with Gracia.
Consequently, Morihiro HOSOKAWA and subsequent lords of the Kumamoto Domain were related to by blood to Narishige HOSOKAWA but not to the Tadatoshi lineage which had blood ties to Gracia.
Consequently, Morihiro HOSOKAWA and subsequent lords of the Kumamoto Domain were related to by blood to Narishige HOSOKAWA but not to the Tadatoshi lineage which had blood ties to Gracia.

sen.j: 忠興の後を三男の忠利が継いだのは、長男・細川忠隆が廃嫡されたからである。
sen.e: The reason Tadaoki's 3rd son Tadatoshi succeeded him is because his eldest son Tadataka HOSOKAWA was disinherited.
Tadaoki's 3rd son Tadatoshi succeeded because he disinherited his eldest son Tadataka HOSOKAWA.
Tadaoki's 3rd son Tadatoshi succeeded because he disinherited his eldest son Tadataka HOSOKAWA.

sen.j: 忠隆の正室の千世は前田利家の娘であったが、関ヶ原の戦いの際に忠興の妻が大坂屋敷で自害した際に千世は脱出して生き延びていた。
sen.e: Tadataka's wife Chiyo was daughter of Toshiie MAEDA but, during the Battle of Sekigahara when Tadaoki's wife committed suicide in the residence at Osaka Chiyo escaped and survived.
Tadataka's wife Chiyo was daughter of Toshiie MAEDA but, during the Battle of Sekigahara when Tadaoki's wife committed suicide in the residence at Osaka Chiyo escaped and survived.
Tadataka's wife Chiyo, was daughter of Toshiie MAEDA, escaped and survived during the Battle of Sekigahara while Tadaoki's wife committed suicide in the residence at Osaka.
sen.cmt: ’を'に訂正しました。文の構成を訂正しました。

sen.j: 忠興はこれを咎め千世を離縁して前田利長の前田家と縁を切るよう忠隆に命じた。
sen.e: Tadaoki blamed Chiyo and ordered Tadataka to divorce her and to sever all connections with Toshiie MAEDA and the Maeda clan.
Tadaoki blamed Chiyo and ordered Tadataka to divorce her and to sever all connections with Toshiie MAEDA and the Maeda clan.
Tadaoki blamed Chiyo and ordered Tadataka to divorce her and to sever all connections with Toshiie MAEDA and the Maeda clan.

sen.j: しかし忠隆は千世を庇い離縁を承知しなかったため、忠興は忠隆を追放廃嫡とした。
sen.e: However, because Tadataka stood up for Chiyo and would not divorce her, Tadaoki exiled and disinherited Tadataka.
However, Tadataka stood up for Chiyo and would not divorce her, and so Tadaoki exiled and disinherited him.
However, Tadataka stood up for Chiyo and would not divorce her, and so Tadaoki exiled and disinherited him.

sen.j: そのため後に忠隆は千世と長男を連れて京都で隠居した。
sen.e: For that reason, henceforth Tadataka retired from public life in Kyoto with Chiyo and his eldest son.
As a result, Tadataka retired from public life and lived quietly in Kyoto with Chiyo and his eldest son.
As a result, Tadataka retired from public life and lived quietly in Kyoto with Chiyo and his eldest son.

sen.j: 次男の細川興秋は、元和元年（1615年）の大坂の役で豊臣方に与したため、戦後に父の命を受けて自害を余儀なくされている。
sen.e: Tadaoki's second son was Okiaki HOSOKAWA who sided with the Toyotomi in 1615 during the Siege of Osaka supplied Toyotomi's side and after the battles was inevitably directed by his father to commit ritual suicide.
Tadaoki's second son was Okiaki HOSOKAWA who sided with the Toyotomi in 1615 during the Siege of Osaka and was subsequently and unavoidably ordered by his father to commit ritual suicide.
sen.cmt: I am not sure that "inevitably" is the best choice or word here. I prefer "unavoidably"
sen.e: Tadaoki's second son was Okiaki HOSOKAWA who sided with the Toyotomi in 1615 during the Siege of Osaka and was subsequently and unavoidably ordered by his father to commit ritual suicide.
